comments.commentBody:
The Constitution doesn't even tell priests how to treat their alter boys. Ordinary male
politicians have zero rights in the issue of abortion. The Congress is acting like the
Vatican Council. Lousy lovers.

Like just about everyone else here who has voiced their opinions about this and other Republican issues we see as backward, ignorant, lacking in any factual evidence, or having any connection to reality in many cases, we still can not say for sure, why some individuals such as Akins believes these things.

I and most of you have our own personal opinions as to why, and in most cases they are probably correct, but what we really need is a way to prove it. We can see from their actions their mentality, we can hear what they say, but what has infected their brains such, that they actually have these delusions.

It looks to me like much of their abnormal mental states come from religious beliefs. They also have a propensity to rewrite history. For instance the history of marriage, which was originally to let others know that the particular woman or women were the property of some ruler or other.

That people like Akins believe as they do about sex and what constitutes rape, tells us what a disturbed mentality they have. It shows us the mind of a psychologically disturbed individual. The lack of condemnation from his right wing supporters shows us just how cowardly they are. Now that is my opinion of them from my observations and I would like to be able to lock them up and study them under clinical conditions.

By the way, where in the Constitution does it give others the right to tell a doctor how he can treat his patients?

CAF, you've pretty much said it. When I saw this one, I just shook my head. The fox guarding the henhouse and all that.

Meanwhile, these former "public servants" are fiddling while Rome burns. AGW is coming down now — right now — and we're dickering about dubious studies instead of doing something about the future.

God bless the child that's got his own

And they try to scare us about Sharia law--alien law taking over. The GOP are the American Taliban using their own sharia law to take over a modern democracy that actually has a constitution & bill of rights. That makes this situation unique. Seems our celebrated democratic political culture and laws, as they stand, are in reality, a weak opposition for this power grab.

Women's health rights, senior safety net, voting rights, public institutions of all kinds are threatened. But about half of our citizens accept this, according to polls. The GOP Sharia party is actually competing well with Obama.
Is this unique in the history of modern democratic nations? I think it is.

@MH: The gender bias depends on the company culture, but it's certainly there. The age bias is rampant.. The software company I work for has trouble filling people, and it's not because the number of applicants is small. The applicants keep pouring in, but the hiring manager prefer people with only "3-7"years of experience" which is basically a sly way of saying 30 or under.

The excuses range from "pay" to "culture clash", but the bottom line is illegal discrimination that nobody wants to challenge or do anything about.

I have been a computer engineer since 1980 and can testify that sexism is alive and well. Whether in universities, where my daughter is currently obtaining a masters in Computer Engineering, or in industry where "boys clubs" rule. The beginnings of the discrimination can be trace back to males in universities (and lower grades) involved in computer hardware and software courses tend to cluster effectively ostracizing women from their team. I

"Coding well" and acquiring knowledge does have to involve face to face social interaction. "Coding well" is a group effort as no one creates her or his own code from nothing. There are standards which development groups must come to agreement on from which languages to use to how to comment the code to which compilers (and the associated switches) to environmental variables; all of which can wreak havoc.

I had the pleasure of putting together a development team at one company I worked for that consisted of five women. Two were Q/A engineers from MS and jumped ship because they hit a glass ceiling trying to move into development. One had her masters in CS from an Israeli university yet was having trouble finding work. And the other two moved from other companies because of perceived discrimination. These women created one of the best teams I've had the pleasure to work with the end result of an excellent product. The simple fact is that all these women were discriminated against despite being highly capable.

Discrimination (in the form of unequal societal standards) is actually at the heart of what drives women away from choosing technical careers in the first place. Women feel that they need to absolutely excel to stay in a technical career in order to avoid having their qualifications questioned (so that people won't think "she only there because she's a woman"). The same thing happens to men in certain fields of the humanities and performing arts.

And as the article notes, a lot of women didn't make it past the interview stage because the interviewers didn't take into account the fact that women tend to downplay their accomplishments while men tend to embellish them.

Thank you for stating the obvious that our PC ( and I don't mean Personal  Computer) culture so energetically tries to obscure.  I don't see such hand-wringing over the lack of men in nursing or elementary-school teaching.

Computer science is fairly blind to diversity. You can either code well or not, and acquiring the knowledge doesn't have to involve face to face social intersection. Reminds of a story I heard about auditions for the Chicago Philharmonic where the musicians pay from behind a curtain to obscure their personal details. I've been recruiting engineers in NYC for more than a decade and of the thousands of candidates, I only remember seeing a handful of non-Asian women. Discrimination doesn't keep women out of technology; they're simply not choosing it as a career path. And more so than other disciplines, diversity hires of non-qualified candidates just means someone else had to clean up the mess, which doesn't benefit anyone as code doesn't care about gender or color.

But note that the official Republican party platform would outlaw abortion in all cases, no exception for rape, incest, the life or health of the mother.  So Akin is right in line with that, even though he's basing his beliefs on idiocy.
They are screaming at him to shut up because he announced their own policies and plans so clearly, and in such a way that people actually noticed.  Look at the party platform!

A week before the Convention, the Republicans are stepping over each other to denounce and distance themselves from Todd Akin's medieval remarks on "legitimate" rape. Close by were the troubling, self-contradictory remarks of Paul Ryan (and of Mitt himself) set in motion a couple of weeks ago that the Republicans were asked to answer, which continues unabated.

What a set of precursors to the Convention in Tampa, FL next week ! On the top of Todd A., Paul R. and Mitt R., now comes Isaac, the thunderstorm heading toward Tampa. And we are NOT talking about economy, jobs etc. !
I think the problem is that "record" companies are run by old white men, whereas social media has their ear to the ground.  Old school no longer works....sit up and take notice.
And we have the chutzpah to pontificate to Middle Eastern countries about THEIR treatment of women.

All this religiously based talk about sex and procreation stems from one thing- the control of women.  In no traditional (read that to mean pre-enlightenment) religious or common law establishment do women have any authority or leadership role.  They are chattels, mere property, whose own inheritance was immediately forfeited to their husbands on their marriage day.  It never was about respect for life- not that of the mother or her Downs fetus.  It was always about the men, draped in robes or business attire, who used their mystical ceremonies or the trappings of the law to control and subjugate women, and thereby solidify their own power and privilege.

Manitoban, never get sick. Never love anyone who does. Never get laid off. Never get part-timed.

If you do, no matter how hard you've worked, how many taxes you've paid in your lifetime, how kind you've been--people like you, Manitoban, will declare you a "person who doesn't produce".

I have no illusions that mercy will infect you, or any such thing. But until you understand that the market is not a god that doles out money based on merit, you will continue to contribute to the incredible meanness that now infests this once-great nation.

Kip,

Amusing freudian slip here:

"one 'iffy' crap a year to three dependable crops"

I kind of like it the way you typed it. ;-)

I'm curious. How does this program seem to be working? Do you see sustainable changes in the local approaches to farming or does it require continued support at the same level?

One could only hope (or work hard for, I suppose; hope probably has nothing to do with it) such efforts would get going across the border in Haiti.

You'd get my vote.

And I agree, many of my associates have the knee-jerk on nuclear, yet Asteroid Miner makes intriguing points with tight logic. So, I am in your camp. After all, look at France, and all of the highly accomplished folks that insist that a decarbonized future is out of the question "sans nucléaire". My mind is open for sure, yet, despite repeated assurances that questions of H20 requirements are hyperbolic, they still appear legitimate. Yet here again, its not a one dimensional matter, and water might simply be one of the negatives in an overall net plus.

And it seems that Thorium is still stuck in the lab. Perhaps it needs more of those evil subsidies that fossil fuel enthusiasts decry (except for of course, when they are receiving them).

Stop using "QED."

It's that know-it-all smugness that got you stuffed in your locker in high school.
Great back-of-the envelope tally. Thanks.

Wind represented 3.4% of installed capacity as of December 31, 2010. And it generated 2.9% of all electric energy in 2011. Hardly the difference between a wedge and a single pixel.

Next time, you can check your facts here http://www.eia.gov/

I suggest you do so before enlightening the rest of us.

It was private companies like Countrywide and their ilk that led the charge, not government-led, although GW Bush's "ownership society" push contributed greatly to the bubble.  Make no mistake, however, it was Wall Street that was behind the securitization, and of course, B of A, Citi--the banks and investment houses that could work together to pull the long con after Glass-Steagal was repealed.

A close call because of his distinguished record of public service? Practically EVERYONE has qualities for which they can be commended. But that isn't the issue here. The issue is that he's on the industry dole. For that, the industry expects to get what it wants. It's a close call only if you believe that lobbyists aren't partisan.
And it's nice of President Obama to oblige them.

Yes, JMA, we all believe that President Bush had nothing to do with the calamities that happened in the eight long years in which he presided over a nation falling apart worse every year that he was the "decider".  Very clear.

I read in the Times' Opinions that GOP economics will spirit us back to the 19th Century, into the heyday of the Robber Barons. I likewise read that the GOP's fervent religiosity will reseed the good old USA with the Calvinistic Puritanism of 17th Century.

But just a little further reading, outside the generous pages of the Times, indicates that GOP economics will restore feudalism, and its religiosity restore the Medieval Catholic Church.

Cor bilmey, as the Brits say around here. And voters should realize this is a shortening the timeless Medieval oath: God blind me.

The world we live in is in real trouble when people like Akins get elected. For the longest time I have not believed we were in an economic recession but rather an economic depression. Now I changed my mind. After listening to the Akins and the GOP I believe we are in a terminal civil regression that makes the American economic spirit depressed.

I still want to see his taxes. When you run for President of the US you must provide your income tax so we can see where your money comes from and what kind of taxes you pay. We want to see if you are acceptable for us to trust you as our President. If you don't you will never get elected. Your attitude toward women and our rights is despicable. The majority of  women won't vote for him either.
Do hospitals get tax exemptions, loopholes or deductions for being a hospital when they file their taxes? If they do then they shouldn't be able to turn down medicare patients.

Great post gemli, getting to the hear of the matter. My though is: what if half the voters are co opted into joining the insecure, fearful zealots? What if billionaires are supporting the propaganda that turns voters into True Believers? What if these acts of violence are simply redefined in order to rationalize what is essentially cruelty? Our voting is not effectively protecting us from these zealots, and not able to bring the U.S. into the modern world.
Electing Romney won't make it happen.

I think you have to couch your statements on public spaces in the context of the US and to a lesser extent Canada. The situation is very different in many European countries, for example France and Belgium. Local media photographers and broadcasters are very aware of privacy laws protecting even public spaces. Very often they have to hide faces by blurring them out or get permission from everyone shown. The public is very aware of this right. I have had many confrontations with people asserting that right. One only has to look at what Google had to do to keep its "street view" from being shut down in France and Germany to understand the law.
Slides 8 and 9 are delightful.
